children.text: Goal 1.1: Understand Systems, Order, and Organization
Match the parts of a system.
Arrange and organize a group of related objects that form a whole.
Sort items from different systems.
Communicate different characteristics of systems.
Arrange small systems as a part of a whole system.
Identify small systems that contribute to the function of the whole.
Identify different structures of an organisms, such as body parts, tissues, or organs.
Demonstrate understanding of a system.
Use a model to display order & organization to a given system.
Demonstrate understanding of a system.
Use a model to display order & organization to a given system.
Demonstrate understanding of a system. .
Use a model to display order & organization to a given system.
Goal 1.2: Understand Concepts and Processes of Evidence, Models, and Explanations
Make and communicate observations.
Make and communicate observations.
Make observation and collect data.
Make observations, collect and record data.
Attend to and/or replicate scientific models.
Make and record observations and then communicate the collected data
Identify when an observation is or an inference is made.
Replicate or make models.
Use observations and data to make predictions.
Identify the difference between an observation and an inference.
Replicate or make a model to demonstrate a concept.
Respond to observations and data as recorded on a chart.
Identify relative data to use in an inference.
Replicate or make a model to explain or demonstrate a concept.
Compare and contrast relative data.
Identify observation data to use in defendable inferences.
Use models to explain or demonstrate a concept.
Compare and contrast relative data.
Compare and contrast relative data.
Compare and contrast relative data.
Use models to explain concepts or systems.
Develop a scientific explanation based on known data.

Goal 1.3: Understand Constancy, Change, and Measurement
Measure in nonstandard units.
Measure in nonstandard units.
Measure in standard or non-standard units.
Measure changes that occur.
Communicate observed change.
Demonstrate changes that occur in systems.
Demonstrate changes that occur in systems.
Identify systems that have been stable over time.
Recognize changes that occur within systems.
Measure in U.S. Customary System of Measurement.
Measure in U.S. Customary System of Measurement or the metric system.
Make measurements using appropriate tools in the metric or U.S. Customary System of Measurement.
Measure changes that can occur in systems.
Respond to changes that can occur in systems.
Measure using the metric system or U.S. Customary System of Measurement.
Measure changes that can occur in systems.
Respond to changes that can occur in systems.
Measure using the metric system or U.S. Customary System of Measurement.
Measure changes that can occur in and among systems.
Respond to changes that can occur in and among systems.
Measure using the metric system or U.S. Customary System of Measurement.
Measure in U.S. Customary System of Measurement.
Measure in U.S. Customary System of Measurement.
Goal 1.4: Understand the Theory that Evolution is a Process that Relates to the Gradual Changes in the Universe and of Equilibrium as a Physical State
Demonstrate the concept of days.
Demonstrate the concepts of yesterday, today, and tomorrow.
Demonstrate the concepts of past, present, and future.
Goal 1.5: Understand Concepts of Form and Function
Sort objects by shape.
Sort common objects by use.
Communicate the relationship between shape and use.
Respond how the shape or form of an object or system is frequently related to its use or function.
Identifies how the shape or form of an object is frequently related to its use and/or function.
Goal 1.6: Understand Scientific Inquiry and Develop Critical Thinking Skills
Make observations.
Make and record observations.
Make observations, collect, and record data.
Respond to questions about observation.
Generate questions about observations.
Follow steps in scientific test.
Identify questions that can be answered by conducting scientific tests.
Follow steps in scientific tests.
Identify questions that can be answered by conducting scientific experiments.
Observe change in scientific investigations using a control and a variable.
Identify questions that can be answered by conducting scientific experiments.
Observe change in scientific investigations using a control and variables.
Identify a control and a variable in an experiment.
Use appropriate tools and techniques to gather and display data.
Identify questions that can guide scientific investigations.
Communicate results of investigations.
Identify questions that can guide scientific investigations.
Communicate results of investigations.
Identify questions that can guide scientific investigations.
Identify the basic components of an experiment design.
Choose information for evidence.
Communicate observations.
Use appropriate tools to gather data.
Use data for a reasonable explanation.
Make simple predictions based on data.
Select reasonable explanations.
State a result of a test to others.

Use data for a reasonable explanation.
Make simple predictions based on data.

Use data for a reasonable explanation.
State a prediction or hypothesis based on observations.
Compare reasonable explanations and predictions.

Use data for a reasonable explanation or prediction.
Test a prediction or hypothesis based on observations.
Communicate scientific procedures.
Use data in order to form conclusions.
Use evidence to accept or reject a hypothesis.
Use reasonable explanations or predictions.
Communicate scientific procedures and explanations.
Select and use appropriate technology to make investigations.
Construct explanations and/or models using evidence.
Select alternative explanations and models.

Compare the differences among observations.

Goal 1.7: Understand That Interpersonal Relationships Are Important in Scientific Endeavors
Use cooperation and interaction skills.
Demonstrate cooperation and interaction skills.
Practice cooperation and interaction skills.
Goal 1.8: Understand Technical Communication
Follow one step instruction.
Follow instructions.
Follow instructions
Follow multi-step instructions.
Follow multi-step instructions.
Follow technical instructions.
Follow technical instructions.
Read and follow technical instructions.
Use graphs, charts, and diagrams.
Use graphs, charts, and diagrams.
Use graphs, charts, and diagrams.
Goal 2.1: Understand the Structure and Function of Matter and Molecules and Their Interactions
Use senses to sort properties of matter.
Identify properties of objects.
Identify properties of an object.
Observe & match physical properties to solids, liquids, or gases.
Use instruments to measure properties.
Observe that heating and cooling can cause changes of state in common materials.
Observe the physical properties of solids, liquids, and gases.
Use instruments to measure properties.
Communicate the changes caused by heating and cooling materials.
Create mixtures
Describe the physical differences among solids, liquids, and gases.
Observe a physical change and how it relates to physical properties.
Compare mixtures.
Identify properties of matter.
Describe the effects of temperature.
Compare density of equal volumes of a solid and a liquid.
Show a physical change and how it relates to its physical properties.
Goal 2.2: Understand Concepts of Motion and Forces
Observe the position and motion of objects. (ex. revolve, rotate, at rest, float, and fall)
Communicate how force affects the position and motion of objects.
Observe and identify the effects of different forces (gravity and friction) on speed or movement.
Observe motion using Newton’s Laws of Motion.
Goal 2.3: Understand the Total Energy in the Universe is Constant
Observe potential and kinetic energy.
Show and communicate that energy can be transformed but cannot be created nor destroyed.
Sort energy as potential and/or kinetic.
Goal 2.4: Understand the Structure of Atoms
Identify the location of protons, neutrons, and electrons.
Demonstrate a simple process of fission and fusion.
Identify a characteristic of an isotope.
Identify matter that has basic electrical properties.
Identify matter that have magnetic properties.
Goal 2.5: Understand Chemical Reactions
Observe and identify how chemicals react.
Goal 3.1: Understand the Theory of Biological Evolution
Observe the characteristics of plants and animals.
Observe the life cycle of a plant (seed, growth, death).
Sequence a simple life cycle of an animal (birth, development, death).
Identify when plants and animals adapt to their environment.
Communicate how plants and animals adapt to their environment.
Communicate the difference between vertebrate and invertebrate animals.
Sort into groups of vertebrates (mammal, reptiles, amphibians, birds, and fish) based on characteristics.
Communicate how natural selection explains species change over time.
Show how a species has changed over time.
Goal 3.2: Understand the Relationship between Matter and Energy in Living Systems
Sort between living and non-living things.
Observe that living things need food to survive.
Identify basic needs of all living things (food, shelter, water, space).
Match animals to their suitable habitats.
Select the energy needed for a living system to survive.
Identify how energy requirements of plants and animals are different.
Organize a food chain.
Develop a food web.
Communicate how plants need energy from the sun.
Identify that energy stored in food is primarily derived from the sun.
Show how the availability of resources limits organisms.
Illustrate how atoms and molecules make up living and nonliving resources in the environment.
Show how energy flows through the ecosystem in one direction.
Show that matter tends to undergo spontaneous changes.
Show that organisms need continuous energy and matter to maintain life.
Identify the sun as the primary source of energy for life.
Identify that respiration involves the release of energy.
Show how matter cycles and energy flows through a living system.
Goal 3.3: Understand the Cell is the Basis of Form and Function for All Living Things
Explore plant and animal cells.
Identify traits that are passed from parents to offspring.
Identify the difference between cells, organs, organ systems and organism.
Compare the structural differences between plant and animal cells.
Identify traits that are passed from parents to offspring.
Sequence the relationships of cells, tissues, organs, organ systems, and organisms.
Label parts of plant and animal cells.
Identify different functions of particular cell structures.
Describe the functions of particular cell structures.
Communicate how dominant and recessive traits are inherited.
Identify a cell and its particular structures.
Identify different functions of particular cell structures.
Identify that cells store information for transferring to the next generation of cells.
Identify how the role of genes plays in differentiation.
Goal 4.1: Understand Scientific Theories of Origin and Subsequent Changes in the Universe and Earth Systems
Observe characteristics of the four seasons
Sequence the seasons
Identify characteristics of the four seasons.
Identify characteristics of different weather conditions.
Identify how the sun relates to the length of a day and/or the seasons on Earth.
Identify basic components of our solar system (planets, sun, moon, asteroids, or comets).
Demonstrate how gravity affects orbits and objects.
Explore how the Earth’s tides change.
Discuss how the interactions among the solid earth, oceans and atmosphere (erosion, climate, tectonics and continental drift) are connected.
Illustrate the water cycle and its relationship to weather and climate.
Discuss how clouds relate to weather changes.
Identify interactions among the solid earth, oceans, atmosphere, and organisms that are connected.
Identify terms used in geological time.
Show interactions among the solid earth, oceans, atmosphere, and organisms have changed.
Compare and contrast the basic components of our solar system (planets, sun, moon, asteroids, comets, meteors).
Goal 4.2: Understand Geo-chemical Cycles and Energy in the Earth System
Label the rock cycle.
Identify internal & external energy sources of the earth.

text: Standard 5: Personal and Social Perspectives; Technology

children.text: Goal 5.1: Understand Common  Environmental Quality Issues, Both Natural and Human  Induced
Attend to and participate in discussion of characteristics of a man-made environment (home, school…).
Match the characteristics of local natural environments. (playground, backyard).
Sort man-made and natural environments
Recognize local environmental issues.
List issues for environmental studies.
Identify issues for environmental studies.
Identify environmental issues, issues such as water and air quality, hazardous waste, depletion of natural resources.
Identifies environmental issues such as water, air, or trash.
Goal 5.2: Understand the Relationship between Science and Technology
Explore tools that people have invented for everyday life and for scientific investigations.
Explore how technology helps develop tools.
Order the development of tools over time.
Attends to discussion of tools used for space exploration and for scientific investigations.
Demonstrate how science and technology are part of a student’s life.
List examples of science and technology.
Identify how science and technology are part of our society.
Identify when science and technology are interrelated.
Identify how science and technology are interrelated.
Show how science advances technology.
Show how science and technology are interrelated.
Show how technology advances science.
Identifies different purposes for science research and technology.
Show how science and technology are interrelated.
Show how technology advances science.
Identifies different purposes for science research and technology.
Identifies an improvement science research has made in technology.
Show how technology advances science
Identifies different purposes for science research and technology.
Goal 5.3: Understand the Importance of Natural Resources and the Need to Manage and Conserve Them
Uses methods of recycling.
Sort resources as renewable and nonrenewable resources.
Identifies between renewable and nonrenewable resources
Identify an alternative source of energy.
Identifies between renewable and nonrenewable resources.
Identifies between renewable and nonrenewable resources.
